content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

EDITED : previously binary output, so changed the clash a bit ( outputting closest prime product to a number instead of whether a number is a prime product ).

Feel free to give feedback on my edit

From the contribution guidelines :

Binary or language-specific outputs should be avoided in CoC.

Some output formats favor specific languages and make the contribution unbalanced. Binary outputs open the door to "cheating" solutions to get around 50%.

I don't see why this has been accepted when all recent contributions have been rejected for that exact reason.

Also, why isn't there a test case where n is prime?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A fine clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A gentle problem.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice One for CoC.
can be a good practice for beginners
I like this problem not only it's easy to understand, but it's the perfect type of problems for fastest mode in clash.
Please publish it. I would like to approve.
maybe add a prime number as well as a test case? that edge case does not seem to be covered by the tests
The problem is easy to understand and is challenging enough for a clash. The test cases are also good.

I like the challenge. But (as someone said to me in previous days with a similar condition) a binary answer (true or false) is not a good idea. Because by simply print("true") you can have more or less 50% chance of success.
I suggest to you to simply change the statement to solve several n in each run. (This annoying because that require a lot of work to create inputs/outputs, but this is the solution to avoid the binary problem.)

To the people who are just downvoting without any comment:

If you could elaborate why you are downvoting, I would have the chance to improve my contribution. Otherwise, just downvoting would not help me in anyway!

Thanks for commenting.
There is no any particular reason for selecting the numbers that I have used in this CoC, and I don't think there needs to be any reason whatsoever.

I just thought of a number, checked it if it is prime product or not, and added it to the test cases and validators.

I don't think 10 test cases are too many, are they?

I shall remove some of them if other people also think this many test cases are not required.

I don't think the binary problem would be much to worry about. In order for someone to win a clash of code, they need to do better than their competitors. Somebody that only prints "true" isn't going to beat anyone who actually solves the problem.
I know, but few weeks ago someone rejected my proposition for this reason.
